flashcard.title: Hello
flashcard.definition: A common greeting word
flashcard.example: Hello, how are you?

flashcard.title: Play
flashcard.definition: To take part in a game or sport
flashcard.example: I play football every weekend.

flashcard.title: Ubiquitous
flashcard.definition: Present, appearing, or found everywhere
flashcard.example: Mobile phones have become ubiquitous in modern society. You see them in cafes, on public transport, and even in remote villages. Their ubiquitous presence has changed how we communicate.

flashcard.title: Nevertheless
flashcard.definition: In spite of that; notwithstanding; all the same
flashcard.example: The weather forecast predicted heavy rain all day. Nevertheless, we decided to go ahead with our hiking trip, packing our best waterproof gear. Surprisingly, the sun came out in the afternoon.

flashcard.title: Break down
flashcard.definition: To stop functioning; to analyze in detail
flashcard.example: My old car broke down on the highway during rush hour, causing a huge traffic jam. Later, the mechanic helped me break down the repair costs into parts and labor.

flashcard.title: Serendipity
flashcard.definition: The occurrence of events by chance in a happy or beneficial way
flashcard.example: Finding that rare book in the small corner shop was pure serendipity. I wasn't even looking for it; I had just gotten lost and wandered in. That chance discovery led me to a whole new research topic.

flashcard.title: Run out of
flashcard.definition: To use all of something so that nothing is left
flashcard.example: Halfway through baking the cake, I realized I had run out of sugar. I had to quickly run to the neighbor to borrow some. It's so frustrating to run out of essential ingredients like that.

flashcard.title: Benevolent
flashcard.definition: Well meaning and kindly
flashcard.example: The benevolent old man donated most of his wealth to build a school and a hospital in his hometown. His benevolent actions were not for fame, but stemmed from a genuine desire to help his community prosper.

flashcard.title: Bite the bullet
flashcard.definition: To endure a painful or unpleasant situation that is unavoidable
flashcard.example: After months of agonizing over the expensive car repair, I finally decided to bite the bullet and pay for it. I knew the cost would hurt my savings, but having a reliable car for work was non-negotiable.

flashcard.title: Consequently
flashcard.definition: As a result; therefore
flashcard.example: The factory ignored the new environmental regulations for years. Consequently, it caused significant pollution to the local river, which led to a massive fine and a mandatory shutdown for cleanup operations.

flashcard.title: Ephemeral
flashcard.definition: Lasting for a very short time
flashcard.example: The beauty of cherry blossoms is famously ephemeral. The flowers bloom spectacularly for just a week or two before the petals fall like pink snow, reminding us of the fleeting nature of such perfect moments.

flashcard.title: Look forward to
flashcard.definition: To await eagerly; to anticipate with pleasure
flashcard.example: After this long and stressful project, I genuinely look forward to taking a proper vacation. I've already started planning it—I look forward to sleeping in, reading on the beach, and completely disconnecting from work emails.

flashcard.title: Implement
flashcard.definition: To put a plan, system, or decision into effect
flashcard.example: The city council voted to implement a new recycling program starting next quarter. Implementing it will require distributing new bins, educating residents, and setting up new collection routes, which is a complex logistical challenge.

flashcard.title: Robust
flashcard.definition: Strong and healthy; vigorous. Also, (of a system) able to withstand or overcome adverse conditions.
flashcard.example: We need a robust argument to defend our thesis in front of the review panel. It must be backed by robust data from multiple sources, as any weak point will be heavily scrutinized. A robust immune system also helps you recover faster from illness.

flashcard.title: Nuance
flashcard.definition: A subtle difference in or shade of meaning, expression, or sound.
flashcard.example: Understanding the nuance between 'happy' and 'content' is important for a writer. 'Happy' is more energetic and joyful, while 'content' implies a peaceful, satisfied stillness. This subtle nuance can change the entire feeling of a character description.

flashcard.title: Dilemma
flashcard.definition: A situation in which a difficult choice has to be made between two or more alternatives, especially equally undesirable ones.
flashcard.example: She faced a terrible dilemma: accept the high-paying job in a city she hated, or stay in her beloved hometown with limited career prospects. It was a classic dilemma between financial security and personal happiness, with no easy answer.

flashcard.title: Ambiguous
flashcard.definition: Open to more than one interpretation; not having one obvious meaning.
flashcard.example: The manager's feedback was frustratingly ambiguous. He said my report was 'interesting,' which could mean he found it thought-provoking or, conversely, that it was strange and missing the point. Such ambiguous language leaves too much room for doubt.

flashcard.title: Inevitable
flashcard.definition: Certain to happen; unavoidable.
flashcard.example: With the rapid melting of polar ice caps, rising sea levels seem inevitable. Coastal cities are starting to plan for this inevitable future, building sea walls and reconsidering construction in flood-prone areas.

flashcard.title: Scrutinize
flashcard.definition: To examine or inspect closely and thoroughly.
flashcard.example: The committee will scrutinize every line of the proposed budget. They will look for any unnecessary expenses or errors, as public funds must be spent with absolute transparency. Be prepared for them to scrutinize your calculations in detail.

flashcard.title: Pragmatic
flashcard.definition: Dealing with things sensibly and realistically in a way that is based on practical rather than theoretical considerations.
flashcard.example: Her pragmatic approach to the crisis saved the company. Instead of waiting for a perfect theoretical solution, she implemented a good-enough, practical fix immediately to stop the financial bleeding, then refined it later.

flashcard.title: Give up
flashcard.definition: To stop trying to do something; to quit.
flashcard.example: After failing the driving test three times, he was tempted to give up. His instructor encouraged him, saying, 'Don't give up now, you're so close to getting it right!' Sometimes, not giving up is the hardest part of achieving a goal.

flashcard.title: Find out
flashcard.definition: To discover a fact or piece of information.
flashcard.example: I need to find out what time the meeting starts tomorrow. I'll call the secretary to find out the exact location as well. It's always better to find out these details in advance to avoid any last-minute panic.

flashcard.title: Bring up
flashcard.definition: To mention a subject; to raise a child.
flashcard.example: During the dinner, she carefully brought up the topic of a salary raise. It was a difficult conversation to have with her boss. Separately, her parents did a wonderful job bringing her up to be kind and resilient.

flashcard.title: Turn down
flashcard.definition: To reject an offer or request; to reduce volume or intensity.
flashcard.example: He had to turn down the amazing job offer in New York because his family couldn't move. It was a heartbreaking decision. Could you also turn down the music a little? I'm trying to concentrate.

flashcard.title: Look after
flashcard.definition: To take care of someone or something.
flashcard.example: Could you look after my cat while I'm on vacation next week? You'll need to feed her twice a day and look after her litter box. It's a big responsibility to properly look after someone's pet.

flashcard.title: Piece of cake
flashcard.definition: Something very easy to do.
flashcard.example: After studying advanced calculus, this basic algebra test was a piece of cake. I finished it in half the allotted time. Don't worry about assembling the furniture; with these instructions, it'll be a piece of cake.

flashcard.title: Spill the beans
flashcard.definition: To reveal secret information, usually accidentally.
flashcard.example: We were planning a surprise party for Sarah, but her brother spilled the beans a day before. He casually asked her what time she'd be home on Saturday, which made her instantly suspicious and ruined the surprise completely.

flashcard.title: Hit the nail on the head
flashcard.definition: To describe exactly what is causing a situation or problem.
flashcard.example: When you said the team's problem is a lack of clear communication, you absolutely hit the nail on the head. That's the core issue we need to address. Your analysis of the market trend really hit the nail on the head.
flashcard.collocation: You hit the nail on the head
flashcard.pastTense: Hit the nail on the head
flashcard.pastParticiple: Hit the nail on the head

flashcard.title: Burn the midnight oil
flashcard.definition: To work or study late into the night.
flashcard.example: The students had to burn the midnight oil for weeks to finish their final thesis projects. You could see the library lights on until 3 AM, filled with people burning the midnight oil before the submission deadline.

flashcard.title: Get out of hand
flashcard.definition: To become difficult to control.
flashcard.example: The protest started peacefully, but it quickly got out of hand when a small group began throwing objects. The situation got so out of hand that the police had to intervene to restore order. We need to address this issue before it gets out of hand.

flashcard.title: Furthermore
flashcard.definition: In addition; besides (used to introduce a fresh consideration in an argument).
flashcard.example: The plan is too expensive. Furthermore, it relies on technology that isn't yet proven to work reliably. We must consider these financial and technical risks before proceeding any further with this proposal.

flashcard.title: Therefore
flashcard.definition: For that reason; consequently.
flashcard.example: All the flights have been canceled due to the severe storm. Therefore, we have no choice but to postpone our trip until next week. We will, therefore, need to reschedule all our client meetings as well.

flashcard.title: However
flashcard.definition: Used to introduce a statement that contrasts with or seems to contradict something that has been said previously.
flashcard.example: The initial test results were very promising. However, when we scaled up the experiment, we encountered several unexpected problems. These issues, however, are not insurmountable with more research.

flashcard.title: In addition
flashcard.definition: As an extra person, thing, or circumstance.
flashcard.example: You will receive a full refund for the defective product. In addition, we would like to offer you a 20% discount on your next purchase as an apology for the inconvenience caused. In addition to this, our customer service will follow up personally.

flashcard.title: On the other hand
flashcard.definition: Used to introduce a contrasting point of view, fact, or argument.
flashcard.example: Living in a big city offers great career opportunities and cultural events. On the other hand, it is often very expensive and can feel crowded and impersonal. On the other hand, village life is quiet but may lack certain amenities.

flashcard.title: Analysis
flashcard.definition: Detailed examination of the elements or structure of something.
flashcard.example: The data analysis revealed a surprising trend: sales actually increased during the economic downturn among a specific age group. This deep analysis forced us to rethink our entire marketing strategy and target demographic for the upcoming campaign.

flashcard.title: Strategy
flashcard.definition: A plan of action designed to achieve a long-term or overall aim.
flashcard.example: The company's new digital marketing strategy focuses on creating engaging video content for social media. This strategy is based on extensive research showing that our target audience spends most of their online time watching short-form videos.

flashcard.title: Innovation
flashcard.definition: The action or process of innovating; a new method, idea, product, etc.
flashcard.example: True innovation often comes from questioning the basic assumptions of an industry. The innovation of the smartphone wasn't just a better phone; it was a radical rethinking of a pocket computer that could also make calls, which disrupted multiple markets at once.

flashcard.title: Efficient
flashcard.definition: Achieving maximum productivity with minimum wasted effort or expense.
flashcard.example: The new software made the billing process incredibly efficient. Tasks that used to take two hours are now completed in twenty minutes. An efficient workflow not only saves time but also reduces errors and employee frustration.

flashcard.title: Algorithm
flashcard.definition: A process or set of rules to be followed in calculations or other problem-solving operations, especially by a computer.
flashcard.example: The social media platform's algorithm determines what content appears on your feed. It analyzes your past clicks, likes, and time spent on posts to predict what will keep you engaged. Understanding this algorithm is key for content creators.
